title: Inventory and profile all user-related tables across the e-commerce schema
description: Systematically identify and profile all tables and views that contain user-related data (e.g., customers, accounts, users, auth, profiles, orders with embedded user info). Steps: (1) Scan schema metadata for columns like user_id, customer_id, account_id, email, login, and phone; (2) Generate a list of candidate tables and key columns; (3) For each table, compute row counts, distinct counts for user identifiers, null ratios, and overlap with the canonical user identifier (if known); (4) Classify each table as core user master, satellite (attributes), or derived/analytic; (5) Produce a consolidated inventory document (table name, key columns, purpose, owner, data freshness). Output will be used to define the canonical User entity and mapping rules.

title: Define canonical User entity mapping to customers/accounts/users tables
description: Using the user-related table inventory, define a canonical User entity and map it to concrete physical tables (e.g., customers, accounts, users, auth_users). Steps: (1) Select the primary source of truth for user identity (e.g., users.user_id or customers.customer_id) based on uniqueness, completeness, and governance ownership; (2) Define mapping rules between canonical User.id and each physical key (e.g., users.user_id, accounts.account_id, customers.customer_id, email-based joins where necessary); (3) Specify handling of duplicates and conflicts (e.g., same email in multiple tables, multiple accounts per user); (4) Document mapping logic in a technical spec (including join conditions, filters, and precedence rules); (5) Align with downstream consumers (analytics, CRM, marketing) on the canonical identifier to use. Deliverable: a mapping specification ready for implementation in ETL/ELT or semantic layer.

title: Document User entity attributes and relationships in the data dictionary
description: Create a comprehensive data dictionary entry for the canonical User entity. Steps: (1) List all User attributes (e.g., id, email, name, signup_date, status, segment, marketing_opt_in) and define business meaning, data type, allowed values, and source tables/columns; (2) Document relationships from User to key e-commerce entities (Orders, Carts, Sessions, Payments, Support Tickets, Email_Sends, Leads) including cardinality and join keys; (3) Capture data quality expectations (e.g., email must be unique per active user, signup_date not null for active users); (4) Add examples and edge cases (guest checkout, merged accounts, deleted users); (5) Publish in the central data catalog or documentation tool and tag with domain=e_commerce and owner. This documentation will be the reference for analytics, engineering, and marketing teams.

title: Validate email-to-conversion attribution logic with Marketing stakeholders
description: Review and validate the proposed conversion attribution logic that links email_sends to conversion events (e.g., orders, signups) with the Marketing team. Steps: (1) Present the current technical design: how email_send_id or recipient email is joined to conversions, attribution window (e.g., 7 days post-send), and multi-touch rules; (2) Walk through concrete examples from recent campaigns (e.g., a user receiving multiple emails before a purchase) and show how attribution is assigned; (3) Collect feedback on business rules (e.g., last-touch vs first-touch, handling of opens vs clicks vs impressions); (4) Agree on final attribution rules and document any exceptions (e.g., transactional emails excluded, internal test campaigns excluded); (5) Obtain sign-off from Marketing and Analytics leads. Output: approved attribution specification that will guide implementation.

title: Implement email-to-conversion attribution model in analytics layer
description: Build and deploy a production-ready attribution model that connects email_sends to conversion events (e.g., orders, signups, key e-commerce events). Steps: (1) Implement the agreed attribution rules (from the validated spec) in the data warehouse or analytics layer (e.g., dbt models, stored procedures, or ETL jobs); (2) Define input sources: email_sends (campaign_id, email_send_id, recipient, send_time), user identity (User entity), and conversion events (orders, checkouts, registrations) with timestamps; (3) Implement logic for attribution window, multi-touch handling (e.g., last non-transactional email within 7 days), and campaign exclusions; (4) Create derived tables/views for campaign performance (conversions, revenue, AOV, unsubscribe impact) at campaign and user level; (5) Validate results against a sample of campaigns with Marketing and Analytics; (6) Schedule regular runs and integrate with BI dashboards. Deliverable: reproducible, documented attribution model powering marketing performance reporting.

title: Document attribution window and multi-touch rules for email marketing
description: Create clear documentation of the attribution assumptions used for email marketing performance in the e-commerce domain. Steps: (1) Describe the attribution window (e.g., conversions within 7 days of send are eligible) and rationale; (2) Specify multi-touch logic (e.g., last-touch, first-touch, linear, or position-based) and how multiple emails from different campaigns are handled; (3) Document special cases: transactional emails excluded, re-engagement campaigns, abandoned cart flows, and cross-channel interactions (e.g., paid ads vs email); (4) Include examples with timelines showing how a single conversion is attributed when multiple emails are sent; (5) Publish this in the marketing analytics playbook and link it to the data dictionary entries for email_sends and conversions. This ensures consistent interpretation of campaign performance across teams.

title: Set up monitoring for email attribution accuracy and confidence calibration
description: Implement ongoing monitoring to track the accuracy and stability of the email-to-conversion attribution model. Steps: (1) Define key quality metrics: share of conversions with attributed email, distribution of attribution windows, anomalies in campaign-level conversion rates, and consistency across cohorts; (2) Build automated checks comparing model outputs to baseline expectations (e.g., historical averages, control campaigns); (3) Flag suspicious patterns (e.g., sudden drop in attributed conversions, spikes for specific campaigns) and route alerts to Analytics/Marketing; (4) Periodically sample attributed conversions and manually validate against raw event logs and CRM data; (5) Adjust model confidence scores or business usage (e.g., for budgeting) based on observed accuracy; (6) Log monitoring results for audit and governance. This ensures the attribution model remains reliable as email strategy and site behavior evolve.

title: Implement performant join path between leads.email and email_sends.recipient
description: Create a reliable and performant linkage between leads and email_sends using email as the join key. Steps: (1) Confirm canonical email formats and normalization rules (e.g., lowercase, trimming, handling of plus-addressing) for both leads.email and email_sends.recipient; (2) Implement a foreign key constraint where possible or, if cross-system, create indexed columns and a standardized join pattern in the warehouse; (3) Add supporting indexes on leads.email and email_sends.recipient (or their normalized equivalents) to optimize attribution and funnel analysis queries; (4) Backfill and validate that containment between leads.email and email_sends.recipient remains at or near 100% (as per discovery metrics); (5) Document the join pattern and any known exceptions (e.g., bounced emails, unsubscribes, test addresses). This enables robust lead-to-email engagement and conversion analysis.

title: Document email marketing attribution logic for analytics consumers
description: Produce consumer-focused documentation explaining how email marketing attribution is implemented and how to correctly use it in analytics. Steps: (1) Summarize the technical model in non-technical terms (what counts as an attributed conversion, which events are included, which are excluded); (2) Describe key fields in the attribution tables/views (e.g., attributed_campaign_id, attributed_email_send_id, attribution_type, attribution_window_days); (3) Provide example queries for common use cases: campaign performance, cohort analysis, incremental lift estimation, and user-level engagement funnels; (4) Clarify limitations and caveats (e.g., cross-device tracking gaps, guest checkout behavior, email forwarding); (5) Link to underlying data dictionary entries and governance policies. This ensures analysts and business users interpret attribution metrics consistently.

title: Configure data quality checks for leadsâ€“email_sends containment
description: Set up automated data quality checks to ensure that the containment relationship between leads.email and email_sends.recipient remains at (or very close to) 100%. Steps: (1) Implement daily or hourly checks that compute containment and Jaccard similarity between leads.email and email_sends.recipient (or their normalized forms); (2) Define alert thresholds (e.g., containment drops below 99.5% or sudden changes >1% day-over-day); (3) Integrate checks into the existing data quality framework (e.g., Great Expectations, Monte Carlo, custom SQL checks); (4) Route alerts to the data platform or marketing data owner with clear remediation guidance (e.g., investigate new lead source, email provider changes, or ETL failures); (5) Log historical quality metrics to track long-term trends and support audits. This protects the reliability of lead-to-email attribution and downstream funnel analysis.
